docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: Local Court General Division Appeals to the Supreme Court

heading.title: Local Court Practice Guide
Local Court General Division Appeals to the Supreme Court
Local Court General Division Appeals to the Supreme Court
Local Court General Division Appeals to the Supreme Court

p.text: Legislation cited in [25,005] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 Div 4, ss 39, s 39(1), 40, s 40(1), s 40(2).
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 [SCA s 75A], s 75A(4), s 75A(5).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 50.16, UCPR r 50.5(1), UCPR r 50.5(3), UCPR r 50.5(4).
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 57(1)(a).

heading.title: The grounds for appeal

level.toc-caption: [25,005.5] Who may appeal and on what grounds?

heading.title: Who may appeal and on what grounds?

p.text: A party to proceedings under LCA 2007 Pt 3 who is dissatisfied with a judgment or order of a Local Court sitting in its General Division as being "erroneous in point of law" has a right of appeal to the Supreme Court: LCA 2007 s 39(1) .
If a question of "mixed fact and law" is involved, leave of the Supreme Court is necessary: LCA 2007 s 40(1) .
If the appeal involves:
an interlocutory judgment or order;
a judgment or order made with the consent of the parties;
an order as to costs a costs order,
leave of the Supreme Court is necessary: s 40(2) .
As to appeals from a Local Court sitting in its Small Claims Division, see the separate commentary on the Small Claims Division at [22,001] .

Appeals to the Supreme Court are provided for in Supreme Court Act 1970 s 75A at [SCA s 75A] . Section 75A(4) provides that the section has effect “subject to any Act”. Relevantly, this means subject to the LCA 2007 ss 39(1) and 40(1) , dealing respectively with appeals on questions of law and mixed fact and law. In dealing with such appeals, even if an error of law (or mixed fact and law) is demonstrated, the Supreme Court has no authority to engage in fact finding on the merits of the case (B & L Linings Pty Ltd v Chief Commission of State Revenue [2008] NSWCA 187; BC200807313 at [38]–[70] per Allsop P, at [144]–[150] per Basten JA). As regards the applicability of this principle to Local Court judgments which are the subject of appeal, see Nichols v Lee [2008] NSWSC 1243; BC200810319 at [61] . UCPR r 50.16 (which provides that the appeal is to be by way of rehearing) cannot operate to alter the form of the appeal which is created by ss 39 –41 of the Local Court Act by giving either an appellant or respondent to an appeal either a rehearing or a hearing de novo: Ken Wolf Real Estate Pty Ltd v O’Halloran [2012] NSWSC 993; BC201206781 , per Beech-Jones J at [50]. Kostas v HIA Insurance Services Pty Ltd (2010) 241 CLR 390; 270 ALR 228; [2010] HCA 32; BC201007173 distinguished.

Although the appeal to the Supreme Court is described as one “by way of rehearing” ( s 75A(5) ), this does not involve a fresh hearing of the evidence: Builders Licensing Board v Sperway Constructions (Syd) Pty Ltd (1976) 135 CLR 616 at 620; 14 ALR 174; [1976] HCA 62; BC7600124 per Mason J; Turnbull v New South Wales Medical Board [1976] 2 NSWLR 281 at 297–8 per Glass JA. Nor does it enable an appellate court to make findings of fact for the purpose of determining what orders should be made: Ken Wolf Real Estate, op cit , and the cases therein cited at [52]. The power of the Supreme Court to make findings of fact which were not made by the trial judge in circumstances where the issue did not arise at trial is limited: Sullivan v Stefanidi [2009] NSWCA 313; BC200909050 .

level.toc-caption: [25,005.7] Section 40(1), (2): the significance of the requirement of leave to appeal

heading.title: Section 40(1), (2): the significance of the requirement of leave to appeal

p.text: The purpose of a requirement of leave to appeal is that it is intended to act as a filter to ensure that unsuitable appellate proceedings are not able to be brought with the demands which that places upon the resources of the court and the burden which it places upon other parties and the delays which it causes to other litigants. This is so particularly where small claims are involved: Young v Kruger [2012] NSWSC 628; BC201204371 (per Harrison AsJ at 11); Ion v Danutz [2012] NSWSC 941; BC201206965 (per Harrison JA at [14]–[15]. These principles encapsulate a line of authority recently enunciated by Basten JA in Be Financial Pty Ltd as Trustee for Be Financial Operations Trust v Das [2012] NSWCA 164; BC201203956 at [32], [33] and [35] to the effect that:
An applicant for leave must demonstrate something more than that the trial judge was arguably wrong in the conclusion arrived at: Carolan v AMF Bowling Pty Limited [1995] NSWCA 69 per Sheller JA.

Where small claims are involved, it is important that there be early finality in determination of litigation, otherwise the costs that will be involved are likely to swamp the money sum involved in the dispute: Carolan per Cole JA. Zelden v Sewell; Henamast Pty Ltd v Sewell [2011] NSWCA 5 per Campbell JA, Young JA concurring at [22].

Ordinarily it is appropriate to grant leave to appeal “only concerning matters that involve issues of principle, questions of general public importance or an injustice which is reasonably clear, in the sense of going beyond [what is] merely arguable": Jaycar Pty Ltd v Lombardo [2011] NSWCA 284 per Campbell JA, Young and Meagher JJA concurring at [46].

A leave requirement is a preliminary procedure "recognised by the legislature as a means of enabling the court to control in some measure the volume of appellate work requiring its attention" Coulter v The Queen [1988] HCA 3; (1988) 164 CLR 350 at 356 (Mason CJ, Wilson and Brennan JJ). Per Basten JA in Be Financial at [35]: “That statement is clearly applicable to civil, as well as criminal, appellate jurisdiction”.

level.toc-caption: [25,005.8] Section 40(2)(c): seeking leave to appeal against a costs order

heading.title: Section 40(2)(c): seeking leave to appeal against a costs order

p.text: It is extraordinarily difficult to show that a court of first instance or a tribunal with wide discretionary powers has erred in the exercise of its powers to award costs, if there is some basis for making an order other than the conventional order in favour of the successful party.

The Court may do so where an error in principle is identified, where the judge acted on a manifestly erroneous view of the facts, or where the award is manifestly unreasonable. But the applicant must satisfy a high threshold for such a grant of leave. The test to be applied is not whether the Court of Appeal would have made the same order but whether there is a ground upon which the order by his Honour could reasonably be made. Some manifest error must be exposed to take the case out of the ordinary situation: A Team Diamond Headquarters Pty Ltd v Main Road Property Group Pty Ltd (2009) 25 VR 189; [2009] VSCA 208; BC200908735 , applied by Harrison AsJ in Young v Kruger [2012] NSWSC 628; BC201204371 (leave to appeal against a costs order where the plaintiff was successful but where the Magistrate ordered each party to pay their own costs refused, the suit to recover preference moneys following a liquidation being largely to benefit the liquidator’s and lawyer’s costs, there being no benefit to unsecured creditors).

One instance where leave to appeal against a costs order and the appeal itself were successful involved a magistrate’s decision in the Local Court that the unsuccessful party on a motion pay twice the assessed costs sought by the successful party: Short v Burn [2012] NSWSC 695; BC201204754 (error of law involved; magistrate’s discretion miscarried because of a fundamental misapprehension of the requirements of a fair hearing).

level.toc-caption: [25,005.10] Section 39(1): what is an error of law

heading.title: Section 39(1): what is an error of law

p.text: As to the importance of delineating the question of law for determination and framing it appropriately, see Zogiannis v Stevens [2012] VSC 264; BC201204469 at [4], per Davies J: “Where the grounds do no more than indicate that the subject matter of the proposed appeal invites reconsideration of the merits of the decision, the jurisdiction of the Court is not enlivened, even though the question of law identified may be expressed in judicial review terms. If the question of law properly analysed is not a question of law, the form of its expression does not turn it into a question of law. Questions of fact or questions of mixed fact and law are not turned into pure questions of law merely by embracing language that the Magistrate 'erred in law' or by using formulaic language for grounds of judicial review”.
In RL & D Investments Pty Ltd v Bisby (2002) 37 MVR 479; [2002] NSWSC 1082; BC200206943 , David Kirby J enunciated the relevant principles governing what is a question of law as follows:

A finding of fact by a tribunal of fact cannot be disturbed if the facts inferred by the tribunal, upon which the finding is based, are capable of supporting its finding, and there is evidence capable of supporting its inferences.

Such a finding can be disturbed only (a) if there is no evidence to support its inferences, or (b) if the facts inferred by it and supported by evidence are incapable of justifying the finding of fact based upon those inferences, or, (c) if it has misdirected itself in law: Australian Gaslight Co v Valuer-General (1940) 40 SR (NSW) 126; 57 WN (NSW) 53; 14 LGR (NSW) 149 at 138, per Jordan CJ.

There is no error of law in simply making a wrong finding of fact (Australian Broadcasting Tribunal v Bond , above, per Mason CJ ALD at 13; CLR at 341), unless there is no evidence to support that finding.

It does not amount to an error of law if the finding of fact, or the inference (or the refusal to make a finding of fact or draw an inference) is perverse, in the sense that it is contrary to the overwhelming weight of evidence (Glass JA in Azzopardi v Tasman UEB Industries Ltd , above at 155 );

Historically it is not an error of law even if the reasoning process by which the court reaches its conclusion of fact is demonstrably unsound or illogical (Menzies J in R v District Court of Sydney: Ex parte White (1966) 116 CLR 644 at 654; [1967] ALR 161; (1966) 40 ALJR 337; BC6600830 . However, it seems illogicality in reasoning can now be relied upon as an appeal basis of challenge to facts found or inferences drawn by the primary judge, as demonstrating error of law: AMABA Pty Ltd (under NSW administered winding up) v Booth; AMACA Pty Ltd (under NSW administered winding up) v Booth [2010] NSWCA 344; BC201009428 at [22]-[26] per Basten JA (Beazley and Giles JJA agreeing) citing Re Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; Ex parte Applicant S20/2002 (2003) 198 ALR 59; 77 ALJR 1165; [2003] HCA 30; BC200303044 at [52] ; (McHugh and Gummow JJ, Callinan J agreeing); Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs v SGLB (2004) 207 ALR 12; 78 ALJR 992; [2004] HCA 32; BC200403589 at [38] (Gummow and Hayne JJ); Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v SZMDS (2010) 240 CLR 611; 266 ALR 367; [2010] HCA 16; BC201003365 at [40] (Gummow and Kiefel JJ, dissenting); cf [113 ], [119] and [129 ]–[130] (Crennan and Bell JJ); see also Goodwin v Commissioner of Police [2010] NSWCA 239; BC201006776 at [12] per Basten JA.

There is a limited exception in relation to decisions of fact in the context of a statutory description. In such a case there may be an error of law if the decision on the facts is one which could not be reasonably entertained, or supported, if the tribunal had properly understood the true construction of the relevant enactment (Mahony v Industrial Registrar of New South Wales , above NSWLR at 1 per Hope JA and NSWLR at 5 per Samuels JA).
There will, however, be an error of law in the circumstances described by Mason CJ (Brennan J agreeing) in Australian Broadcasting Tribunal v Bond , above ALD at 23; CLR at 355 :

The question whether there is any evidence of a particular fact is a question of law: McPhee v S Bennett Ltd (1934) 52 WN (NSW) 8 at 9 ; Australian Gaslight Co v Valuer-General (1940) 40 SR (NSW) 126 at 137–8; 57 WN 53 . Likewise, the question whether a particular inference can be drawn from facts found or agreed is a question of law: Australian Gaslight , above, (SR (NSW)) at 137–8 ; Hope v Bathurst City Council (1980) 144 CLR 1 at 8–9; 29 ALR 577 . This is because, before the inference is drawn, there is the preliminary question whether the evidence reasonably admits of different conclusions: FCT v Broken Hill Douth Ltd (1941) 65 CLR 150 at 155, 157, 160 . So, in the context of judicial review, it has been accepted that the making of findings and the drawing of inferences in the absence of evidence is an error of law: Sinclair v Maryborough Mining Warden (1975) 132 CLR 473 at 481; 5 ALR 513 .

In Bisby , Kirby J remitted the matter to the Local Court because, in certain areas, the magistrate had made findings of “no evidence”, whereas in fact there was such evidence. This evidence had therefore not been considered. His Honour took the view that, as the legislation then stood, Local Court General Division appeals were confined to errors of law. However, the legislation has since been amended to include, by leave of the Supreme Court, an appeal encompassing a question of mixed fact and law. Kirby J’s remarks remain relevant on this issue, since the court may well have to determine whether the appeal involves a question of law simpliciter, in which case the appeal is as of right, or a question of mixed fact and law, in which case leave is necessary.
An error of law may also include:
a finding made where there is no evidence to support it or which draws an inference from facts that cannot be reasonably drawn;
a finding that no person acting judicially and properly instructed as to the relevant law could have made; and

the situation where a court has misdirected itself in law: Australian Gas Light Co v Valuer-General (1940) 40 SR (NSW) 126 , a relevant circumstance in Nichols v Lee [2008] NSWSC 1243; BC200810319 : US Manufacturing Co Pty Ltd v ABB Service Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 705; BC200806510 , per Hall J.

It is doubtful whether a wrong finding of a matter of fact (even though liable to be overturned on the grounds referred to in Fox v Percy (2003) 214 CLR 118; 197 ALR 201; [2003] HCA 22; BC200301915 ) amounts to an error of law, or an error of mixed law and fact. What needs to be demonstrated is “that the judgment is unsupportable on facts incontrovertibly established by the evidence, or that no judge acting judicially and having regard to the whole of the evidence could have reached the conclusion that the primary judge did. Put slightly differently, there will be an error of law, or at least one of mixed fact and law, if the judgment given is one that was simply not open on the evidence”: Jaksic v Yim [2011] NSWSC 962; BC201106476 at [13] (Brereton J).

A tribunal which decides a question of fact when there is “no evidence” in support of a finding makes an error of law. What amounts to material that could support a factual finding is ultimately a question for judicial decision. It is a question of law”: Kostas v HIA Insurance Services Pty Ltd t/as Home Owners Warranty (2010) 241 CLR 390; 270 ALR 228; [2010] HCA 32; BC201007173 at [91] per Hayne, Heydon, Crennan, Kiefel JJ. Perverse or unreasonable findings of fact do not of themselves constitute errors of law: Crown Glass & Aluminium Pty Ltd v Ibrahim [2005] NSWCA 195; BC200504671 . However, the NSW authorities demonstrate that a clear distinction should be drawn between the situation where the finding of fact in question is made in favour of a person bearing the onus of proof, and the situation where the finding of fact is made against the person bearing the onus of proof. “In the former situation, the question is not whether there is any evidence at all on the point, but rather whether the evidence on the point is sufficient, in the sense that it is evidence, which if fully accepted could properly base the finding of fact”: at [39], [40], citing Ambulance Service of New South Wales v Daniel (2000) 19 NSWCCR 697 at 711; [2000] NSWCA 116; BC200002229 (in eq). Findings of fact may be infected with errors of law giving rise to grounds for appeal by leave: Raoul v Yamaha Motor Finance Australia Pty Ltd [2009] NSWSC 1363; BC200911087 at [6] per Schmidt J (magistrate’s findings of fact open to him and not infected with legal error).

A failure to give reasons on issues going to the credibility of a witness may, in the context of the case, amount to an error of law: McCarthy v NRMA Insurance [2002] NSWSC 1011; BC200206496 . Saying that one prefers the evidence of one party or its witnesses over the other without analysing why, particularly where there are issues of credibility involved, also constitutes an error of law: Hadid v Redpath (2001) 35 MVR 152; [2001] NSWCA 416; BC200107191 .

“It is unnecessary in a case such as the present involving a collision between two vehicles for a Magistrate to give an elaborate discussion of the evidence and the issues raised in the course of cross-examination of the witnesses”: Walker v Lee [2011] NSWSC 108; BC201101828 at [98] per Hall J (no question of law or error identified). As to the obligation to give reasons generally, see [LCA 07 s 7.15] .

The question of whether a tribunal has overlooked a submission “‘worthy of serious consideration’ is a question of law”: Dennis Willcox Pty Ltd v Federal Commissioner of Taxation (1988) 14 ALD 794; 79 ALR 267; 14 ACLR 156; 88 ATC 4292; 19 ATR 1122 , cited by Jacobson and Bennett JJ at [143] in Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) v Saxby Bridge Financial Planning Pty Ltd (2003) 133 FCR 290; 202 ALR 450; [2003] FCAFC 244; BC200306494 but not all such failures will amount to such. It will depend upon the circumstances of the case: Dennis Willcox v Federal Commissioner of Taxation, above per Jenkinson J (with whom Woodward and Foster JJ agreed) at 276; Moffitt JA in Pettitt v Dunkley [1971] 1 NSWLR 376 at 389 ; see also Leduva Pty Ltd v NM Structural Engineering Pty Ltd [2010] NSWSC 1164; BC201007809 per Garling J at [28] ff. The erroneous rejection of admissible evidence gives rise either to a question of law or a mixed question of law and fact: Short v Burn [2012] NSWSC 695; BC201204754 (erroneous rejection of affidavit because it did not provide a residential address). See also the cases on denial of procedural fairness at [LCA07 s 39.10] and [22,010.110] .

Absent any question of implied terms, the question whether an agreement exists and what are the terms of the agreement is a question of fact: McHugh JA in Empirnall Holdings Pty Ltd v Machon Paull Partners Pty Ltd (1988) 14 NSWLR 523 at 535 , cited by way of submission in Leduva , above, at [68].

heading.title: Other questions of law

p.text: In Minister for Aboriginal Affairs v Peko-Wallsend Ltd (1986) 162 CLR 24; 66 ALR 299; [1986] HCA 40; BC8601448 , the High Court set out a number of general propositions relating to the delineation of a question of law in areas of statutory interpretation and legal terminology: the question as to whether a word or phrase in a statute is to be given its ordinary meaning or some technical or other meaning is a question of law; the ordinary meaning of a word or its non-legal technical meaning is a question of fact; the meaning of a technical legal term is a question of law; the effect or construction of a term whose meaning or interpretation is established is a question of law; the question whether facts fully found fall within the provision of a statutory enactment properly construed is generally a question of law (relevant citations appear): Collector of Customs v Pozzolanic Enterprises Pty Ltd (1993) 43 FCR 280; 115 ALR 1; [1993] FCA 456; BC9304888 ; Garcia v Motor Accidents Authority of New South Wales [2009] NSWSC 1056; BC200909118 .

There may also be instances where an inferior court or tribunal identifies a wrong issue, asks a wrong question, ignores relevant material, relies on irrelevant material, makes an erroneous finding or reaches a mistaken conclusion: Craig v South Australia (1995) 184 CLR 163 at 179; 131 ALR 595; BC9506437 , per Brennan, Deane, Toohey, Gaudron and McHugh JJ; see also Kirk v Industrial Relations Commission of New South Wales (2010) 239 CLR 531; 262 ALR 569; [2010] HCA 1; BC201000230 at [67] . Such areas may well overlap: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs v Yusuf (2001) 206 CLR 323; 180 ALR 1; [2001] HCA 30; BC200102757 . These principles were enunciated in the context of jurisdictional error, but for present purposes the areas identified may well comprise errors of law under LCA 2007 s 39(1) .

level.toc-caption: [25,005.15] Distinguishing questions of law from questions of fact

heading.title: Distinguishing questions of law from questions of fact

p.text: There is no universally applicable test for distinguishing questions of law from questions of fact: Collector of Customs v Agfa-Gevaert Ltd (1996) 186 CLR 389 at 394; 141 ALR 59; 43 ALD 193; BC9605933 ; Sood v R (2006) 201 FLR 119; 165 A Crim R 453; [2006] NSWCCA 114; BC200602241 at [30]. The formulation "question of law" employs general words capable of application at different levels of generality: Attorney-General (NSW) v X (2000) 49 NSWLR 653 at 660; [2000] NSWCA 199; BC200004289 at [25]. The expression "question of law" is wider than "error of law": Attorney-General (NSW) v X (2000) 49 NSWLR 653; [2000] NSWCA 199; BC200004289 at 124. A mixed question of fact and law does not fall within the description of "question of law alone": Williams v R (1986) 161 CLR 278 at 287 and 314; 66 ALR 385; 60 ALJR 636; BC8601452 ; Attorney General (NSW) v X at [44]: Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) (NSW) v Illawarra Cashmart Pty Ltd (2006) 67 NSWLR 402; [2006] NSWSC 343; BC200602646 at [58]–[60], per Johnson J. Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) (NSW) v Linnett (2006) 68 NSWLR 85; (2006) 47 MVR 61; [2006] NSWSC 1086; BC200608338 at [24]–[27] per Buddin J.

If the ultimate fact in issue involves a term used in a statute, the question as to whether the facts adduced to prove or disprove that ultimate fact will always be a question of law: Hayes v FCT (1956) 96 CLR 47 at 51; 30 ALJR 96; BC5600540 ; Collector of Customs v Agfa-Gevaert Ltd (1995) 186 CLR 389; 141 ALR 59; [1996] HCA 59; BC9605933. See also Collector of Customs v Pozzolanic Enterprises Pty Ltd (1993) 43 FCR 280 at 287; 115 ALR 1 at 9; [1993] FCA 456 :
The question whether a word or phrase in a statute is to be given its ordinary meaning or some technical or other meaning is a question of law;
The ordinary meaning of a word or its non-legal technical meaning is a question of fact;
The meaning of a technical legal term is a question of law;
The effect or construction of a term whose meaning or interpretation is established is a question of law;
The question whether facts fully found fall within the provision of a statutory enactment properly construed is generally a question of law

but when a statute uses words according to their ordinary meaning and it is reasonably open to hold that the facts of the case fall within those words, the question as to whether they do or do not is one of fact: (FCR) at 394–5, (ALR) at 10. “[T]hough the meaning of an ordinary English word used in a statute is a question of fact, not of law, nevertheless a finding by a tribunal of fact can be disturbed if the facts inferred by it or which can only be inferred by it from the evidence are necessarily within the description of the word or phrase in the state and the tribunal has made a contrary finding. In that situation its decision is wrong in law”: Williams v Evans [1966] 1 NSWR 245; 84 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 288 , per Asprey and Holmes J.

“A finding of fact … may nevertheless reveal an error of law where it appears that the trial judge has misdirected himself, ie has defined otherwise than in accordance with law the question of fact which he has to answer … Further an ultimate finding of fact, even in the absence of a misdirection, may reveal error of law if the primary facts found are necessarily within or outside a statutory description and a contrary decision has been made, Hope v Bathurst City Council (1980) 144 CLR 1 at 10; 29 ALR 577; 54 ALJR 345; BC8000075 ; Australian Gaslight Co v Valuer-General (1940) 40 SR (NSW) 126 at 138; 57 WN 53 at 55; 14 LGR (NSW) 149 …”: Azzopardi v Tasman UEB Industries Ltd (1985) 4 NSWLR 139 at 156; 9 ALN N245 , Glass JA, with whom Samuels JA agreed, said:

heading.title: Appeals from discretionary decisions

p.text: “The manner in which an appeal against an exercise of discretion should be determined is governed by established principles. It is not enough that the judges composing the appellate court consider that, if they had been in the position of the primary judge, they would have taken a different course. It must appear that some error has been made in exercising the discretion. If the judge acts upon a wrong principle, if he allows extraneous or irrelevant matters to guide or affect him, if he mistakes the facts, if he does not take into account some material consideration, then his determination should be reviewed and the appellate court may exercise its own discretion in substitution for his if it has the materials for doing so. It may not appear how the primary judge has reached the result embodied in his order, but, if upon the facts it is unreasonable or plainly unjust, the appellate court may infer that in some way there has been a failure to properly to exercise the discretion which the law reposes in the court of first instance. In such a case, although the nature of the error may not be discoverable, the exercise of the discretion is reviewed on the ground that a substantial wrong has in fact occurred”: Dixon, Evatt and McTiernan JJ in House v R (1936) 55 CLR 499 at 504–5; 10 ALJR 202 at 207–8 , applied in Ceil Comfort Insulation Pty Ltd v ARM Equipment Finance Pty Ltd [2001] NSWSC 619; BC200104168 at [35] . See also Micallef v ICI Australia Operations Pty Ltd [2001] NSWCA 274; BC200104963 ; Comet Building Services Pty Ltd v Hy-Tec Industries Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 11; BC200800169 at [16] per Campbell J. A discretionary judgment on a matter of practice and procedure can only be overturned in five limited circumstances, where the decision-maker:
made an error of legal principle;
made a material error of fact;
took into account some irrelevant matter;
failed to take into account or gave insufficient weight to some relevant matter; or
arrived at a result so unreasonable or unjust as to suggest that one of the foregoing categories of error had occurred even though such a breach was not apparent on the face of the reasoning.

The general principle which applies to a decision not to vacate a hearing date, or to strike out, or to grant an adjournment, each of which is a discretionary ruling, is that such decisions are matters wholly within the discretion of the court or tribunal dealing with the matter. An appeal against such a decision is an appeal against an exercise of discretion and will be subject to interference by an appeal court only on one of the bases specified in House . However, an appellant court will intervene where the exercise of the discretion in the lower court has the effect of depriving a party of the opportunity to present its case by striking out its defence: Cassar v Hans Pet Constructions Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 1386; BC200811340 (Rothman J) noted at [26,045.10] . The decision was upheld on appeal: Hans Pet Constructions Pty Ltd v Cassar [2009] NSWCA 230; BC200906750 esp at [38]–[41] ; CPA s 57(1)(a) requires the court to have regard to “the just determination of the proceedings” and must be given weight as a fundamental element in the decision making process.

level.toc-caption: [25,005.25] Appeal from the dismissal of an application to set aside default judgment

heading.title: Appeal from the dismissal of an application to set aside default judgment

p.text: An appeal from an application to set aside a default judgment which has been dismissed is an appeal from a "judgment or order" for the purposes of s 73 , and it is not necessary to seek leave to appeal: Cumming v Tradebanc International Ltd [2002] NSWSC 70; BC200200386 at [37] ; N & G Electrical Group Pty Ltd v Terracon Industries Pty Ltd [2002] NSWSC 837; BC200205334 at [5] per Bell J. However, the decision in Carr v Finance Corp of Australia Ltd (No 1) (1981) 147 CLR 246 at 258 at 248; 34 ALR 449; 55 ALJR 397; BC8100070 , does not appear to have been brought to the attention of the Courts which decided those cases, the basic principle being that the test whether a judgment of order was final or interlocutory was whether it finally determined the rights of parties. A default judgment was held not to be in that category, because it was open to a disappointed litigant to apply again to have the judgment set aside. Accordingly, leave is required to appeal against an order dismissing an application to set aside a default judgment: Short v Burn [2012] NSWSC 695; BC201204754 at [23], [24], per Adamson J. Being a discretionary judgment, an application for leave to appeal against the dismissal of an application to set aside default judgment faces significant obstacles: Short v Burn at [61] (but because the trial miscarried and the magistrate applied unreasonable requirements, leave to appeal against the dismissal of the application granted).

heading.title: The parties to the appeal

p.text: Each person who is directly affected by the relief sought in the appeal or is interested in maintaining the decision under appeal must be joined as a defendant to the appeal: UCPR r 50.5(1) . The court may order the addition or removal of a party: UCPR r 50.5(3) . A person must not be made a plaintiff in the appeal without his or her consent: UCPR r 50.5(4) . The appeals regime in LCA 2007 Pt 3 Div 4 provides no avenue of appeal by a stranger to the litigation. LCA 2007 ss 39 and 40 both refer to “a party to proceedings before the Court”.

level.toc-caption: [25,015] The machinery provisions of the appeal

p.text: Legislation cited in [25,015] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 s 39(1), s 40(1), s 41, s 64(2).
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 98.

heading.title: The machinery provisions of the appeal
The time for an appeal

p.text: A summons for appeal must be filed:
within 28 days after “the material date”, that is, the date of the court below’s decision, or

if the appeal relates to the decision of a judicial officer, within such further time as the judicial officer may allow, so long as the application for such further time is filed within 28 days after the “material date”, or
within such further time as the higher court may allow: r 50.3(1) .
An application for an extension of time under subr (1) must form part of the summons commencing the appeal: UCPR r 50.3(2) .
Similar time stipulations apply as regards cross-appeal ( UCPR r 50.10 ) and applications for leave to appeal and cross-appeal ( UCPR rr 50.12 and 50.13 ).

heading.title: Grounds of appeal

p.text: A summons commencing an appeal must state:
whether the appeal relates to the whole or part only, and what part, of the decision of the court below, and

briefly, but specifically, the grounds relied on in support of the appeal including, in particular, any grounds on which it is contended that there is an error of law in the decision of the court below, and
what decision the plaintiff seeks in place of the decision of the court below: UCPR r 50.4 .

The obligation imposed by the rule is to identify with precision the error of law complained of: Nichols v Lee [2008] NSWSC 1243; BC200810319 at [61] , holding that the remarks of the Full Court in ASIC v Saxby Bridge Financial Planning Pty Ltd (2003) 133 FCR 290; 202 ALR 450; [2003] FCAFC 244; BC200306494 at [45]–[48] are also apposite to an appeal to the Supreme Court under the LCA 1982 (now LCA 2007).

heading.title: What must be annexed

p.text: In relation to an appeal, or application for leave to appeal, an affidavit to be relied upon at the appeal must be prepared, filed and served on each defendant not later than 3 days before the date fixed for the hearing of the summons, that annexes or exhibits:
a copy of the reasons for the decision of the court below, unless the court below has not given, and does not intend to give, written reasons, and
a copy of the transcript of the proceedings in the court below, unless a transcript cannot be obtained in respect of proceedings of that type, and

a copy of any exhibit, affidavit or other document from the proceedings in the court below that the plaintiff wishes to be considered at the hearing of the appeal or proposed appeal: UCPR r 50.14(1) .

The defendant may also prepare an affidavit to be relied on at the appeal, cross-appeal or application for leave to appeal or cross-appeal any exhibit, affidavit or other document from the proceedings in the court below that the defendant wishes to be considered at the hearing of the appeal, cross-appeal or application for leave to appeal or cross-appeal: UCPR r 50.14(2) .

The higher court may make further directions for the filing and service of an affidavit under subrule (1) or (2) and for the lodging and service of any exhibits to such an affidavit: UCPR r 50.14(3) .

level.toc-caption: [25,015.20] The nature of an appeal in the Supreme Court

heading.title: The nature of an appeal in the Supreme Court

p.text: UCPR r 50.16(1) would tend to suggest that the appeal is by way of a rehearing, but see [25,005.5] and cf: Ceil Comfort Insulation Pty Ltd v ARM Equipment Finance Pty Ltd [2001] NSWSC 619; BC200104168 at [7], [11] .

level.toc-caption: [25,015.25] Does an appeal operate as a stay?

heading.title: Does an appeal operate as a stay?

p.text: No, “Except so far as the court (or, subject to any direction of the court, the court below) may direct”, according to UCPR r 50.7 . Prima facie the successful plaintiff is entitled to the fruits of his victory: Veritas Property Group Pty Ltd v Ronali Pty Ltd [2012] NSWSC 368; BC201207222 (Eq Div, White J) (matter agitated is an alleged error of fact, not a question of mixed law and fact; grounds for seeking leave to appeal not established; leave to appeal not within Act’s overriding purpose of facilitating just, quick and cheap resolution of issues; application for stay of execution refused). The relevant principles on stays generally are set out at [51.44.5]–[51.44.15] . See also LCA 2007 s 64(2) as regards application proceedings.

level.toc-caption: [25,015.30] Cross-appeals and leave to appeal or cross-appeal

heading.title: Cross-appeals and leave to appeal or cross-appeal

p.text: Cross-appeals are governed by UCPR rr 50.10 . Notice of contention by r 50.11 . Leave to appeal or cross-appeal is governed by UCPR rr 50.12 and 50.13 .

heading.title: Directions for Service

p.text: If the court makes an order granting an extension of time for applying for leave to appeal or cross-appeal, it may also give directions for service under UCPR r 50.15 .

heading.title: The determination of the appeal

p.text: By virtue of the Local Court Act 2007, s 41 , the Supreme Court may determine an appeal:
by varying the terms of the judgment or order; or
by setting the judgment or order aside; or
by setting the judgment or order aside and remitting the matter to the Court for determination in accordance with the Supreme Court's directions; or
by dismissing the appeal: LCA 2007.

“On an appeal under s 39(1) of the Local Court Act, the issues raised by a notice of contention will only arise for consideration at a point where either an erroneous decision by the Local Court on a question of law or, if leave has been granted, on a question of mixed law and fact has been established and the question arises as to what relief, if any, should be granted under s 41 . If the notice of contention raises a pure question of law which is determinative of the case and is resolved in favour of the respondent to the appeal, then the appeal should be dismissed. If it only raises a question of fact determined adversely to the respondent by the Local Court then, consistent with the above authorities, it should not be entertained. If it raises a question of mixed fact and law then the same consideration that attends a grant of leave to an appellant under s 40(1) would attend the court in considering the exercise of its discretion to grant relief and the form of that relief pursuant to s 41 ”: Ken Wolf Real Estate Pty Ltd v O’Halloran [2012] NSWSC 993; BC201206781 , per Beech-Jones J at [53].

heading.title: Costs

p.text: The Supreme Court has wide powers regarding costs. For the general principles relating to costs in civil litigation, see CPA s 98 , UCPR r 42.1 and the notes thereto at [s 98.5] and [42.1.5] respectively

The Justices Act 1902 previously provided a magistrate who had stated a case with protection from any costs in respect of the appeal. However, the new provisions do not. The fact that the magistrate and the Local Court are not parties to the proceedings may not necessarily protect the magistrate from an order for costs, since, subject to UCPR r 42.3 , costs can be awarded against a non-party. In Aavelaid v Magistrate, Local Court Cessnock (NSWSC, Badgery-Parker J, No 11286/90, 20 December 1990, unreported, BC9001576), costs were awarded against a magistrate who had filed a submitting appearance. Costs have also been awarded against magistrates in prohibition proceedings following convictions or orders made in the Court of Petty Sessions where it is seen that the magistrate has clearly misconducted himself or herself, or showed gross ignorance of the law or has acted peremptorily in a fashion amounting to a denial of natural justice. See for example R v Smith (1894) 10 WN (NSW) 171 ; Re Butler; Ex parte Taylor (1924) 41 WN (NSW) 81. The power to order costs was clearly recognised in Ex parte Tranter (1868) 7 SCR (NSW) 213 and Ex parte Cox (1896) 12 WN (NSW) 172 . See also Re Osborn; Ex parte Blume (1958) SR (NSW) 334 cited in Sankey v Whitlam [1977] 1 NSWLR 333 at 363; (1977) 21 ALR 457 .

heading.title: Security for costs

p.text: Under r 50.8(1) , “in special circumstances”, the (Supreme) court may order that such security as the court thinks fit be given of the costs of appeal. Otherwise, no security is required: r 50.8(2) . “Special circumstances” is a notion which is found in many legislative contexts and must therefore take its meaning from the particular context in which it appears. As Spigelman CJ said in relation to a different statutory context in R v Simpson (2001) 53 NSWLR 704; 126 A Crim R 525; [2001] NSWCCA 534; BC200108495 , they are words of “indeterminate reference and will always take their colour from their surroundings.” But in whatever context the phrase appears, the circumstances must be “special”, that is, “out of the ordinary”, “unusual”: R v Baker (2002) 130 A Crim R 417; [2002] NSWCCA 184; BC200203184 , although the specialness must be adjudged in the particular circumstances under consideration: Transglobal Capital Pty Ltd v Yolarno Pty Ltd (2004) 60 NSWLR 143; [2004] NSWCA 136; BC200402460 at [20] . The meaning of special circumstances was also considered in Slade v Gea [2000] NSWSC 806; BC200004675 , where Sperling J applied Abdurahman v Field (NSWCA, Kirby P, Glass, Samuels JJA, 4 March 1986, unreported, BC8601205) to the effect that special circumstances are not made out simply because an appellant has failed to pay costs ordered by the court below. "The court went on to say that, generally speaking, the rule here and in England had been limited in application to cases where there was established a prima facie abuse of process, a gross delay in the proceedings of the appeal, or where it is shown that the appeal is manifestly misconceived and hopeless. The court went on to say later in the judgment that normally the impecuniosity of the appellant is not sufficient to establish special circumstances and to warrant an order for security of costs": at [6] . The applicant for security had sought to rely on certain adverse findings made by the magistrate in the court below as the basis for an apprehension that the appellant would seek to avoid payment of costs of the appeal in the event that costs were awarded against them. Justice Sperling did not share the same apprehension. He was not satisfied that "special circumstances" were established, nor that this was a proper case for the court to exercise its inherent powers to regulate its own procedures by ordering security for a judgment and costs in another court. As to “special circumstances, see also Kennedy v McGeechan [1978] 1 NSWLR 314 (impecuniosity; genuine appeal might be frustrated; liberty of the subject; availability of state-funded legal aid; trifling nature of the subject matter of the appeal; security ordered); Lall v 53–55 Hall Street Pty Ltd [1978] 1 NSWLR 310 (litigant in person making numerous applications surrounding the subject matter of the appeal; security ordered). Cases where it has been held that, normally at least, impecuniosity is not sufficient of itself include: Abdurahman v Field (NSWCA, Kirby P, Glass, Samuels JJA, 4 March 1986, unreported, BC8601205); Maritime Services Board v Citizens Airport Environment Assn Inc (1992) 83 LGERA 107; BC9203007 ; Uptown Sydney Development Corp Pty Ltd v Bank of New Zealand (No 1) (1993) 11 ACSR 300; 11 ACLC 862; BC9303646 per Kirby P; Saba v National Australia Bank Ltd [1999] NSWCA 93; BC9901523 per Sheller JA; McWilliam v Penthouse Publications [1999] NSWCA 2; BC9901579 . Cases in which it has been held that impecuniosity alone may amount to "special circumstances" include: Scerri Northam Holdings Pty Ltd [1967] VR 674 per Winneke CJ (Little and Gowans JJ agreeing; in that case, the Chief Justice referred to the "long and well-established practice of this court" of holding that an appellant's inability to pay the costs of the appeal constituted special circumstances); Ciappina v Ciappina (1983) 70 FLR 287 per Neave J (his Honour relied upon Harlock v Ashberry (1881) 19 Ch D 84 and Kardynal v Dodek [1978] VR 414 as establishing the proposition); Strata Consolidated (Aust) Pty Ltd v Bradshaw [2000] NSWCA 114; BC200002306 per Registrar Jupp; and Citicorp Australia Ltd v Cirillo (2003) 228 LSJS 132; [2003] SASC 204; BC200303574 per Sulan J. The above cases are noted in the New South Wales Court of Appeal’s judgment in Transglobal Capital Pty Ltd v Yolarno Pty Ltd , above, at [28], [29] . The court went on to disapprove Hodgson JA’s comments in Porter v Gordian Runoff Ltd [2004] NSWCA 69; BC200401007 that impecuniosity can of itself amount to special circumstances, and approved the approach of Sheller JA in Saba v National Australia Bank Ltd , above, to the effect that it was not enough for the purposes of UCPR r 51.50(1) (couched in the same terms as the present rule) that the balance of justice or convenience favours the making of an order. In Transglobal , above, the court went on to say that it was also inappropriate to apply a general practice that the other party to the appeal was entitled to be protected and that impecuniosity was sufficient for that purpose. “As the impecuniosity of the appellants was the only matter said to constitute 'special circumstances', and given the matters to which we have referred we are not persuaded that this is an appropriate case for the making of an order for security”: at [37].
